reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central move in the essay’s case for “eutopian fragility”: that plausible single moral errors can wipe out a large fraction of achievable value and thus make the mostly-great/eutopian target narrow. If that claim were false (and typical single-flaw losses were modest), Section 2’s argument for narrowness would be substantially weakened, though the paper’s later Section 3 argument from the structure of value functions (linearity/fat tails/boundedness and bads sensitivity) could still support “no easy eutopia,” so it’s not fully load-bearing (hence centrality < 1). The critique’s strength is moderate: it correctly flags a slide from ‘some views call this catastrophic’ to a stronger cross-view ‘no safe option’ claim, and it presses for an explicit cross-theory magnitude model. However, it mostly asserts rather than argues that losses should be 5–20% and doesn’t engage the essay’s multiplicative/product-of-factors framing, population-ethical scale sensitivity, or the possibility that certain “single flaws” (e.g., digital minds mistreatment) could dominate value on many views. Relevance is moderate: it engages Forethought’s Tier 2 working assumption that eutopia is a narrow target and asks for better quantification/elicitation, but it doesn’t directly resolve an identified Tier 3 internal debate or uncover a new interaction between premises.
title: "Moderate Flaws Need Not Imply Catastrophic Value Loss"
